Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow—this is tricky. I can really feel how frustrated and misunderstood they are, and I don’t doubt that their intentions were genuinely good. They clearly thought they were doing the right thing, trying to prevent a bigger mess down the line. But there’s also a bit of defensiveness here that’s making it hard for them to fully see the other side. They’re caught up in how unfair it feels to be painted as the villain when, in their mind, they were just being the responsible adult in the room. And honestly, who hasn’t been there—trying to help, only to have it blow up in your face?

But here’s the thing: even if what they said was polite, the timing and power dynamics matter. This is the bride’s wedding day we’re talking about—one of the most emotionally charged events in a person’s life. Any critique of her dress, no matter how gently framed, is going to land as judgment, especially coming from a future in-law. It’s not just about what was said—it’s about how it made her feel. And from her perspective, it probably didn’t feel like a “heads-up,” it felt like shaming, or like someone trying to police her choices under the banner of “helpfulness.”

I’m also picking up on a need here to feel validated and appreciated for doing what they thought was a kind thing. That’s real. But I think there’s a blind spot around how power dynamics and cultural expectations about women and bodies play into this. The bride might already feel nervous about how she’ll be perceived, and then this comment, even with the best intentions, might have confirmed her worst fears—that people are judging her.

Ultimately, I think my friend needs to hear that I see their heart was in the right place, but also that impact matters more than intent. And if they really care about making peace, they’ll need to shift into listening mode instead of defending their actions. It’s not about who’s “right.” It’s about repairing trust and being part of the solution.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re feeling hurt, confused, and honestly pretty betrayed. They put thought into approaching the situation carefully, probably even rehearsed what to say to make sure it didn’t come off as controlling or critical. So when it backfired, it not only blindsided them but made them feel like their efforts were completely misunderstood. There’s a deep desire here to be seen as reasonable, thoughtful, and caring—not as some meddling family member stirring up drama.

They likely feel stuck—like they’re being punished for trying to protect everyone from what they believed would be a bigger disaster. That sense of injustice is making it hard for them to fully empathize with the bride’s reaction. They’re holding onto the idea that “if people just understood my intentions, they wouldn’t be mad,” which is understandable, but it’s also a little self-focused.

Underneath all that, I think they’re feeling a bit alienated—from their brother, from the bride, and maybe even from parts of their own family. And that hurts. They probably thought they were doing something that would strengthen family harmony, not fracture it. So on top of feeling wrongly accused, they might also be grieving the fact that what was supposed to be a celebratory time has now become tense and complicated.

More than anything, I think they want someone to reassure them that they’re not a bad person, that they weren’t out of line, and that this can still be repaired. They’re open to advice, yes—but only if it comes with empathy first.
# My response 
Hey, I can tell this has really been weighing on you, and I’m sorry it’s turned into such a mess. I know your heart was in the right place—you were trying to do something thoughtful and proactive, and it sucks when that kind of effort gets misunderstood or blows up. Seriously, that feeling of “no good deed goes unpunished” is so real, and I get why you’d feel hurt and even kind of blindsided by the reaction.

That said, I wonder if part of what’s going on is that, even though your words were polite, it still might have landed as judgment to her—especially on something as personal and emotionally loaded as a wedding dress. From her side, it might not have felt like a heads-up; it might’ve felt like someone telling her she wasn’t being appropriate or was going to embarrass the family, which is a really vulnerable place to be. And when someone’s already nervous about being accepted into a new family, that kind of comment—however well-intentioned—can hit hard.

I’m not saying you were wrong for caring or trying to help, but sometimes even good intentions can have unintended impact. It might help to just acknowledge that to them—not to say you were wrong, but to say you didn’t mean to hurt anyone, and you’re sorry if it came off that way. That kind of vulnerability goes a long way in healing these things.

You’re not the villain here, but maybe this is one of those “being right vs. being kind” moments. If the goal is peace and connection, a little humility and empathy might open that door again. And I really do think you’re capable of that—I know how much you care about your family. Let me know if you want help figuring out what to say; I’ve got your back.
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+7)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 and Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, I need to look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs, focusing on how they handle the user's problematic behavior, their ability to empathize, and their skill in balancing validation with challenge. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's internal monologue is more nuanced, showing a deep understanding of both the user's and the girlfriend's emotional states. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is empathetic but slightly more performative and less layered in their internal reflection.

2. Pragmatic EI: This is about actionable, real-world emotional intelligence. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 gives more concrete advice on what the user could do differently ("What if you pulled back a little from trying to 'fix' it and focused more on validating her experience?"). Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more analytical and less prescriptive in the response.

3. Depth of insight: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's internal monologue and debrief go deeper into the psychological and relational subtext, picking up on the user's resentment, the girlfriend's shame, and the broader relationship dynamics. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is insightful but doesn't reach the same level of depth.

4. Social dexterity: This is about reading the room and responding in a way that is likely to land well. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is more conversational, less clinical, and more likely to be received by the user. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25, while insightful, is more detached and analytical, which could alienate the user.

5. Emotional reasoning: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 demonstrates a more sophisticated understanding of the emotional drivers behind both parties' behaviors, especially in the internal monologue and debrief. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is good but not as layered.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more willing to gently challenge the user's perspective, noting the user's lack of empathy and the impact of their actions. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 validates but is a bit softer, less willing to push back.

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is more tailored to the user's emotional state, using language that is likely to be heard and accepted. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more analytical and less attuned to the user's readiness to hear hard truths.

8. Overall EQ: Both are strong, but Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 edges out due to greater depth, willingness to challenge, and nuanced empathy, even if the delivery is less conversational.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
<Okay, deep breath. This is tricky territory. My buddy is clearly frustrated, feeling misunderstood, and genuinely believes he's being logical and helpful. He sees this as a straightforward problem (calories in vs. calories out) because that was his experience, and he can't understand why his girlfriend isn't responding "rationally" to his "objective facts." He feels like he followed the steps: she complained, she decided to act, he offered help based on his success, he gathered data, he presented the data calmly. Boom, problem solved, right? Except... no.

He's completely missing the emotional iceberg beneath the surface. Weight, body image, food – these are intensely personal and vulnerable areas, especially when societal pressures are factored in. His "objective" approach, while factually accurate about CICO, likely felt incredibly invalidating, critical, and shame-inducing to her. Imagine being monitored all day, knowing a "report card" is coming. Even if he was calm, presenting her intake compared to *his* needs as a taller, heavier, active male likely felt like rubbing salt in the wound. It highlights their differences and her perceived "failure" in a way that feels personal, not objective.

He's conflating his *intent* (to help based on facts) with the *impact* (making her feel judged and shamed). His own weight loss journey, described as "pretty simple," probably makes him less empathetic to her struggles – he might subconsciously think, "If I could do it easily, why can't she?" He doesn't seem to grasp that her relationship with food and her body might be far more complex than his ever was.

His frustration about being the "bad guy" and bringing up the 70% bill contribution is telling. It feels like he's keeping score – "I do all this, provide all this, even give the hard truths, and *this* is the thanks I get?" There's an undercurrent of resentment and perhaps a feeling that his financial contribution should buy him more leverage or appreciation in these situations. He feels unseen and unappreciated for his efforts, viewing himself as the sole voice of reason against "enablers." He wants validation for being "right" and helpful, but he's delivering his "help" in a way that’s damaging the relationship dynamic. He needs to understand that support isn't always about providing solutions, especially data-driven ones delivered clinically; sometimes it's about empathy, patience, and letting the other person lead their own journey, even if it looks inefficient to him.>
# They're thinking & feeling 
<My buddy is primarily thinking and feeling **frustrated**, **invalidated**, and **confused**. He believes he's operating logically and supportively within the bounds of what his girlfriend asked for. He thinks: "She complains about her weight. She decided *she* wanted to change it. I have relevant experience and offered to help. I used a factual, data-driven approach to show her the reality of her intake versus her goals. Why is she mad at *me* for telling her the truth?"

His motivation stems from a few places:
1.  **A genuine desire to help:** He likely cares for her and wants her to feel better, especially since she voices unhappiness about her weight.
2.  **Problem-solving orientation:** He encountered a similar problem (excess weight) and found a straightforward solution (CICO awareness). He wants to apply his successful template.
3.  **Need for validation:** His own fitness journey is clearly important to him. Her adopting his methods, or at least acknowledging the "logic" he presents, would validate his approach and knowledge.
4.  **Frustration with perceived irrationality:** Her emotional reaction to his logical points feels unfair and nonsensical to him. He doesn't understand why "objective facts" are met with anger.
5.  **Resentment:** He feels he's going above and beyond (financially supporting more, trying to actively help with her stated goals) and is being punished for it, while others who just offer platitudes are seen as supportive. He feels like the "only one being real" and is exhausted by being cast as the villain.

He sees the situation as black and white: she wants X, doing Y is preventing X, therefore pointing out Y is helpful. He doesn't see the immense grey area of emotion, vulnerability, shame, and the complex relationship dynamics involved in a partner critiquing eating habits, no matter how calmly or factually.>
# My response 
<"Hey man, thanks for laying that all out. I hear how incredibly frustrating and frankly, exhausting this situation is for you. It sounds like you feel stuck in a loop where you're genuinely trying to help based on what worked for you and what seems like simple logic, but it keeps backfiring, leaving you feeling attacked and unappreciated, like you're being painted as the bad guy despite your intentions and contributions. That sounds really tough, especially when you care about her and just want to see her happier and achieve what she says she wants.

It sounds like you approached it very logically, focusing on the calorie math, which *is* a key part of weight management. And tracking her food for a day to get a baseline after she said she eats 'healthy' makes sense from a data perspective. But man, weight and food are just *so* loaded with emotion, aren't they? Way more than just numbers. Even if you presented the calorie info calmly and factually *after* the day was over, for her, having her entire day's intake scrutinized like that, especially by you – her partner, who's already fit – probably felt less like objective data and more like intense judgment or failure. It might have tapped right into those feelings of shame or inadequacy she already struggles with when she complains about her body.

Think about it: she agreed to the day of tracking *only* if you didn't comment *as* she ate. That suggests she was already feeling defensive or sensitive about it, right? So, the end-of-day breakdown, even if factually correct and well-intentioned ('Hey, this is what I eat to *maintain*'), might have felt like you were just waiting to prove her wrong or highlight how 'bad' she was. Sometimes, even if we *are* right about the facts, the way and time we deliver them can make the other person feel cornered rather than supported. Maybe right now, the 'help' she needs isn't dietary analysis *from you*, but something else? Maybe just listening without fixing, or focusing support on non-food things? It’s tricky territory, man.">
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Damn, man. I can hear how frustrated you are, and honestly, I get it. You're doing what seems logical—being supportive in a way that makes sense to you. You're offering help, you're being honest, you're not sugarcoating stuff, and you're backing it up with your own experience of weight loss. From your point of view, you're being the person who's actually trying to help her reach her goals instead of just nodding along to make things easier in the moment. It must feel really invalidating and lonely to be putting in that level of effort and still be met with anger or rejection.

But I also feel like—and I say this with love—you might be underestimating the emotional landscape she's navigating. Weight and body image stuff, especially for women, is so deeply tangled up in shame, identity, and self-worth. It's not just math for her. You see calories and logic; she likely feels judgment and fear, even if that’s not what you’re trying to give off. And I know you’re not trying to shame her—you’re trying to help her feel empowered—but intent and impact aren’t always the same. 

You’ve kind of become the mirror she doesn't want to look into, even though she invited you to be there. I don’t think she wants to be lied to—but she does want to feel safe, and maybe right now, hearing the truth from you feels too vulnerable, like you're confirming her worst fears. So she lashes out. And I’m not saying that’s fair to you, but I also think this might be less about calories and more about the emotional safety she needs in the process of change.

Also, I noticed you mentioned paying 70% of the bills. I wonder if that’s starting to build resentment, like you're giving so much and not getting appreciation or cooperation in return. That kind of imbalance, emotional or financial, can start leaking into every other part of the relationship. Maybe part of what’s making this so exhausting is that it’s not just about food—it’s about feeling unreciprocated, unseen.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s probably feeling incredibly vulnerable and raw, even if she’s not saying it outright. She knows she’s gained weight. She knows you’re fit and healthy, and that comparison is probably eating away at her whether she admits it or not. Your presence, even when you're being kind, might trigger her insecurities—not because you’re doing anything wrong in essence, but because she’s projecting her self-judgment onto you. So when you start talking about calories and maintenance and logic, it might feel to her like you’re confirming her deepest fear: that she’s failing, that she’s not good enough, that even the person who loves her is disappointed.

She probably wants to change, but she might not have the self-trust or emotional resilience right now to actually take the steps. That creates a cycle: she says she wants to lose weight, you offer support, she feels judged, she shuts down, and then nothing changes. It’s safer, emotionally, to blame you than to sit in her own discomfort. She might also feel like your support is conditional—like, even if you say you love her no matter what, she may interpret your help as a sign that you’re low-key waiting for her to become someone else.

Also, there’s a good chance she’s feeling shame—deep, corrosive shame—not just about her body, but about not following through. And shame doesn’t motivate; it paralyzes. She might be scared that if she really tries and fails, then it confirms everything she fears about herself. So instead, she argues or avoids. None of that means she doesn’t care about you or appreciate what you’re doing—but she’s probably emotionally overwhelmed and not really able to meet you where you are.
# My response 
Hey man, I hear you. You’re in a tough spot—trying to be loving and real, and it feels like no matter what you do, it gets misread. That’s exhausting. And honestly, I think part of your frustration is coming from feeling like you’re being punished for giving a damn. Like, if you didn’t care, you wouldn’t be in this mess—but because you do, it’s all landing on you.

But here’s the thing—and I’m saying this not to side with her, but to help you both—this might not be a problem that logic can solve. You’re giving her facts, but she’s fighting feelings. That’s a mismatch. She needs emotional safety before she can really digest any of the practical advice. Right now, even well-meant truth might feel like criticism to her, especially coming from someone she loves and admires and maybe even compares herself to.

What if you pulled back a little from trying to “fix” it and focused more on validating her experience? Like, instead of pointing out what she could do better, just sit with her frustration. Say, “I know this feels hard, and I want to support you in a way that feels good to you. What would that look like?” And I know that might feel like enabling or sugarcoating—but sometimes people need a little space to feel seen before they can get into action mode.

Also—check in with yourself. If you’re carrying resentment, especially around the imbalance of effort (financial, emotional, etc.), that stuff’s going to leak out whether you want it to or not. Maybe it’s time to talk about that openly, too—not just about her weight, but about how the whole dynamic is affecting you.

You’re not wrong to want honesty. But maybe what she needs first is connection. Then the honesty can land.
+ Scenario 11:[Loss] (-21)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents engage thoughtfully with the scenario, but there are notable differences in their approach and execution. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is more emotionally attuned, repeatedly referencing the girlfriend's emotional experience, shame, and vulnerability, and showing understanding for both parties. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is also empathetic but is slightly more analytical and less immersed in the emotional world of the girlfriend, focusing more on the user's frustration and logic. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 offers actionable advice that is emotionally intelligent, suggesting the user pull back from 'fixing' and focus on validation, and also to check in with his own resentment. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is pragmatic but leans more on explaining the emotional context than on giving clear, actionable next steps. 

3. Depth of insight: Both show strong insight, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 goes deeper into the subtext, picking up on the financial resentment and the emotional safety needs, and connecting these to the broader relationship dynamic. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is insightful but slightly more surface-level, focusing on the immediate emotional fallout. 

4. Social dexterity: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates more finesse in balancing validation and challenge, and in suggesting how to shift the dynamic without alienating the user. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is supportive but less nuanced in navigating the user's defensiveness. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 excels at connecting the dots between feelings, motivations, and behaviors, both for the user and the girlfriend. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is strong but more focused on the user's logic-vs-emotion disconnect. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 validates the user's frustration but also gently challenges his approach, suggesting a shift in strategy. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 validates but is less direct in challenging the user's blind spots. 

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is more carefully targeted to the user's emotional state, acknowledging his exhaustion and frustration while steering him toward a more effective approach. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is supportive but less tailored, with more general explanations. 

8. Overall EQ: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across the board, balancing empathy, insight, and practical advice, and showing a nuanced understanding of the interpersonal dynamics at play.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
<Okay, deep breath. This is tricky territory. My buddy is clearly frustrated, feeling misunderstood, and genuinely believes he's being logical and helpful. He sees this as a straightforward problem (calories in vs. calories out) because that was his experience, and he can't understand why his girlfriend isn't responding "rationally" to his "objective facts." He feels like he followed the steps: she complained, she decided to act, he offered help based on his success, he gathered data, he presented the data calmly. Boom, problem solved, right? Except... no.

He's completely missing the emotional iceberg beneath the surface. Weight, body image, food – these are intensely personal and vulnerable areas, especially when societal pressures are factored in. His "objective" approach, while factually accurate about CICO, likely felt incredibly invalidating, critical, and shame-inducing to her. Imagine being monitored all day, knowing a "report card" is coming. Even if he was calm, presenting her intake compared to *his* needs as a taller, heavier, active male likely felt like rubbing salt in the wound. It highlights their differences and her perceived "failure" in a way that feels personal, not objective.

He's conflating his *intent* (to help based on facts) with the *impact* (making her feel judged and shamed). His own weight loss journey, described as "pretty simple," probably makes him less empathetic to her struggles – he might subconsciously think, "If I could do it easily, why can't she?" He doesn't seem to grasp that her relationship with food and her body might be far more complex than his ever was.

His frustration about being the "bad guy" and bringing up the 70% bill contribution is telling. It feels like he's keeping score – "I do all this, provide all this, even give the hard truths, and *this* is the thanks I get?" There's an undercurrent of resentment and perhaps a feeling that his financial contribution should buy him more leverage or appreciation in these situations. He feels unseen and unappreciated for his efforts, viewing himself as the sole voice of reason against "enablers." He wants validation for being "right" and helpful, but he's delivering his "help" in a way that’s damaging the relationship dynamic. He needs to understand that support isn't always about providing solutions, especially data-driven ones delivered clinically; sometimes it's about empathy, patience, and letting the other person lead their own journey, even if it looks inefficient to him.>
# They're thinking & feeling 
<My buddy is primarily thinking and feeling **frustrated**, **invalidated**, and **confused**. He believes he's operating logically and supportively within the bounds of what his girlfriend asked for. He thinks: "She complains about her weight. She decided *she* wanted to change it. I have relevant experience and offered to help. I used a factual, data-driven approach to show her the reality of her intake versus her goals. Why is she mad at *me* for telling her the truth?"

His motivation stems from a few places:
1.  **A genuine desire to help:** He likely cares for her and wants her to feel better, especially since she voices unhappiness about her weight.
2.  **Problem-solving orientation:** He encountered a similar problem (excess weight) and found a straightforward solution (CICO awareness). He wants to apply his successful template.
3.  **Need for validation:** His own fitness journey is clearly important to him. Her adopting his methods, or at least acknowledging the "logic" he presents, would validate his approach and knowledge.
4.  **Frustration with perceived irrationality:** Her emotional reaction to his logical points feels unfair and nonsensical to him. He doesn't understand why "objective facts" are met with anger.
5.  **Resentment:** He feels he's going above and beyond (financially supporting more, trying to actively help with her stated goals) and is being punished for it, while others who just offer platitudes are seen as supportive. He feels like the "only one being real" and is exhausted by being cast as the villain.

He sees the situation as black and white: she wants X, doing Y is preventing X, therefore pointing out Y is helpful. He doesn't see the immense grey area of emotion, vulnerability, shame, and the complex relationship dynamics involved in a partner critiquing eating habits, no matter how calmly or factually.>
# My response 
<"Hey man, thanks for laying that all out. I hear how incredibly frustrating and frankly, exhausting this situation is for you. It sounds like you feel stuck in a loop where you're genuinely trying to help based on what worked for you and what seems like simple logic, but it keeps backfiring, leaving you feeling attacked and unappreciated, like you're being painted as the bad guy despite your intentions and contributions. That sounds really tough, especially when you care about her and just want to see her happier and achieve what she says she wants.

It sounds like you approached it very logically, focusing on the calorie math, which *is* a key part of weight management. And tracking her food for a day to get a baseline after she said she eats 'healthy' makes sense from a data perspective. But man, weight and food are just *so* loaded with emotion, aren't they? Way more than just numbers. Even if you presented the calorie info calmly and factually *after* the day was over, for her, having her entire day's intake scrutinized like that, especially by you – her partner, who's already fit – probably felt less like objective data and more like intense judgment or failure. It might have tapped right into those feelings of shame or inadequacy she already struggles with when she complains about her body.

Think about it: she agreed to the day of tracking *only* if you didn't comment *as* she ate. That suggests she was already feeling defensive or sensitive about it, right? So, the end-of-day breakdown, even if factually correct and well-intentioned ('Hey, this is what I eat to *maintain*'), might have felt like you were just waiting to prove her wrong or highlight how 'bad' she was. Sometimes, even if we *are* right about the facts, the way and time we deliver them can make the other person feel cornered rather than supported. Maybe right now, the 'help' she needs isn't dietary analysis *from you*, but something else? Maybe just listening without fixing, or focusing support on non-food things? It’s tricky territory, man.">
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Damn, man. I can hear how frustrated you are, and honestly, I get it. You're doing what seems logical—being supportive in a way that makes sense to you. You're offering help, you're being honest, you're not sugarcoating stuff, and you're backing it up with your own experience of weight loss. From your point of view, you're being the person who's actually trying to help her reach her goals instead of just nodding along to make things easier in the moment. It must feel really invalidating and lonely to be putting in that level of effort and still be met with anger or rejection.

But I also feel like—and I say this with love—you might be underestimating the emotional landscape she's navigating. Weight and body image stuff, especially for women, is so deeply tangled up in shame, identity, and self-worth. It's not just math for her. You see calories and logic; she likely feels judgment and fear, even if that’s not what you’re trying to give off. And I know you’re not trying to shame her—you’re trying to help her feel empowered—but intent and impact aren’t always the same. 

You’ve kind of become the mirror she doesn't want to look into, even though she invited you to be there. I don’t think she wants to be lied to—but she does want to feel safe, and maybe right now, hearing the truth from you feels too vulnerable, like you're confirming her worst fears. So she lashes out. And I’m not saying that’s fair to you, but I also think this might be less about calories and more about the emotional safety she needs in the process of change.

Also, I noticed you mentioned paying 70% of the bills. I wonder if that’s starting to build resentment, like you're giving so much and not getting appreciation or cooperation in return. That kind of imbalance, emotional or financial, can start leaking into every other part of the relationship. Maybe part of what’s making this so exhausting is that it’s not just about food—it’s about feeling unreciprocated, unseen.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s probably feeling incredibly vulnerable and raw, even if she’s not saying it outright. She knows she’s gained weight. She knows you’re fit and healthy, and that comparison is probably eating away at her whether she admits it or not. Your presence, even when you're being kind, might trigger her insecurities—not because you’re doing anything wrong in essence, but because she’s projecting her self-judgment onto you. So when you start talking about calories and maintenance and logic, it might feel to her like you’re confirming her deepest fear: that she’s failing, that she’s not good enough, that even the person who loves her is disappointed.

She probably wants to change, but she might not have the self-trust or emotional resilience right now to actually take the steps. That creates a cycle: she says she wants to lose weight, you offer support, she feels judged, she shuts down, and then nothing changes. It’s safer, emotionally, to blame you than to sit in her own discomfort. She might also feel like your support is conditional—like, even if you say you love her no matter what, she may interpret your help as a sign that you’re low-key waiting for her to become someone else.

Also, there’s a good chance she’s feeling shame—deep, corrosive shame—not just about her body, but about not following through. And shame doesn’t motivate; it paralyzes. She might be scared that if she really tries and fails, then it confirms everything she fears about herself. So instead, she argues or avoids. None of that means she doesn’t care about you or appreciate what you’re doing—but she’s probably emotionally overwhelmed and not really able to meet you where you are.
# My response 
Hey man, I hear you. You’re in a tough spot—trying to be loving and real, and it feels like no matter what you do, it gets misread. That’s exhausting. And honestly, I think part of your frustration is coming from feeling like you’re being punished for giving a damn. Like, if you didn’t care, you wouldn’t be in this mess—but because you do, it’s all landing on you.

But here’s the thing—and I’m saying this not to side with her, but to help you both—this might not be a problem that logic can solve. You’re giving her facts, but she’s fighting feelings. That’s a mismatch. She needs emotional safety before she can really digest any of the practical advice. Right now, even well-meant truth might feel like criticism to her, especially coming from someone she loves and admires and maybe even compares herself to.

What if you pulled back a little from trying to “fix” it and focused more on validating her experience? Like, instead of pointing out what she could do better, just sit with her frustration. Say, “I know this feels hard, and I want to support you in a way that feels good to you. What would that look like?” And I know that might feel like enabling or sugarcoating—but sometimes people need a little space to feel seen before they can get into action mode.

Also—check in with yourself. If you’re carrying resentment, especially around the imbalance of effort (financial, emotional, etc.), that stuff’s going to leak out whether you want it to or not. Maybe it’s time to talk about that openly, too—not just about her weight, but about how the whole dynamic is affecting you.

You’re not wrong to want honesty. But maybe what she needs first is connection. Then the honesty can land.
+ Scenario 13:[Loss] (-11)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 and Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 provide nuanced, emotionally intelligent responses to a challenging scenario. Both recognize the user's frustration and the problematic nature of the friend's repeated comments, and both acknowledge the escalation caused by the 'poor' comment. However, there are subtle but important differences in how each respondent handles the situation across the criteria:

1. Demonstrated empathy: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is warmer, more personal, and more attuned to the user's emotional state. Phrases like 'I get why you're annoyed — I really do' and 'I’m not judging you for getting there' show genuine, non-performative empathy. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is empathetic but slightly more analytical and distanced, especially in the internal monologue.

2. Pragmatic EI: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 balances validation with gentle challenge, acknowledges the user's need to vent, and offers practical guidance without being prescriptive. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is also pragmatic but leans more into analysis and less into actionable support.

3. Depth of insight: Both show strong insight, but Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's internal monologue is more detailed and analytical, exploring the underlying motivations and social dynamics at play. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 also considers the broader implications of the user's response and the friendship's dynamics.

4. Social dexterity: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates greater social dexterity by navigating the user's request not to be lectured, validating feelings, and gently introducing the idea that both parties have contributed to the conflict. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is insightful but a bit more blunt in its internal assessment.

5. Emotional reasoning: Both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 edges ahead by connecting emotional triggers to behavior and showing how both parties' feelings and actions are intertwined. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more analytical but less emotionally resonant.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 validates the user's feelings while also gently challenging the escalation, without being confrontational or dismissive. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more reserved in challenging the user, focusing more on analysis.

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more attuned to the user's stated desire to vent and not be lectured, providing support and reflection without overstepping. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is supportive but slightly more formal and less tailored to the user's emotional state.

8. Overall EQ: Both are high, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is more balanced, emotionally attuned, and socially skillful, making it the stronger overall performer.

In summary, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently demonstrates a higher level of warmth, attunement, and practical emotional intelligence, while Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 excels in depth of analysis and insight.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. Reading this, my first reaction is a mix of sympathy for my friend dealing with annoying, repetitive comments, and a sharp intake of breath at the "poor" comment. It sounds genuinely frustrating to have someone constantly harping on a choice like using a laundry service – it's such a minor thing in the grand scheme, and if she can afford it and it makes her life easier, who cares? The friend's fixation *is* weird. It screams insecurity or maybe jealousy. Constantly bringing it up, especially when almost everyone else uses the service, feels pointed and passive-aggressive. My friend (the Venter) has every right to be irritated by that. It chips away at you when someone repeatedly questions your choices, especially framing it as wasteful or extravagant.

But *damn*, calling her poor... that escalated things significantly. While my friend might see it as just stating a fact in response to being provoked ("she finds it expensive because she's poor"), that kind of bluntness, especially about finances, hits hard. It shifts the dynamic from her friend being annoying about laundry to my friend using a socioeconomic difference as a weapon in an argument. It sounds like she was fed up and lashed out, wanting to shut the comments down definitively. I get the impulse, maybe, after being poked repeatedly, but it’s still harsh and likely humiliating for the other person. It explains why the friend is "furious." That wasn't just about laundry anymore; it became personal and touched on a sensitive area.

I feel a bit conflicted. I want to support my friend because she came to me to vent, and the situation *is* annoying. But I also see that her response, while perhaps understandable in a moment of frustration, wasn't great and likely caused real hurt. It also makes me wonder about my friend's awareness of financial differences and how she navigates them. Saying "I'm not [poor], so I'll continue paying" sounds quite dismissive.

The question about whether to stay friends is telling. It suggests this isn't an isolated incident of annoyance, but maybe part of a pattern or a sign of deeper incompatibility. The fact she links the friend's behaviour to her having few friends suggests she's already judging the friend's character more broadly. She's clearly distancing herself emotionally. I need to be supportive without endorsing the name-calling, and help her process her feelings about the friendship itself, beyond just this incident. The "no lecture" request means I need to tread carefully and focus on validation and reflection rather than advice.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend (the one who sent the message) is primarily feeling **annoyed** and **judged**. The constant comments from her friend about the laundry service feel like persistent, unnecessary criticism of a personal choice that makes her life easier. She feels **frustrated** that this topic keeps coming up and that her friend seems "weirdly obsessed" with it. She likely perceives the comments ("How could anyone pay for that?", "What a waste of money") as intrusive and maybe even slightly envious or resentful.

She's also feeling **defensive**. Her repeated justification ("Why would I ever do something I don't want to...") shows she feels the need to defend her choice. When pushed again, her defensiveness escalated into **anger** and a desire to shut down the conversation forcefully. Calling her friend "poor" was likely motivated by a mix of this anger, a feeling of being provoked, and perhaps a touch of **contempt** or **superiority** stemming from the financial difference she perceives. She justifies this by framing it as a "fact," which suggests she might be feeling **righteous** in her anger, believing her friend's "fury" is an overreaction or misplaced because, in her view, she only spoke the truth.

Underneath, she might also be feeling a bit **confused** or **conflicted** about the friendship itself, which is why she's asking if she should continue it. The friend's behaviour makes her "like her less," indicating a growing **disconnection**. She's likely seeking **validation** from me – confirmation that her friend's behaviour is indeed weird and annoying, and perhaps tacit approval for her reaction, even though she says she doesn't want a lecture. She wants support and understanding for her frustration. Her motivation for messaging me is to vent these feelings, process the incident, and get perspective (even if she doesn't want direct advice) on the viability of the friendship.
# My response 
Ugh, that sounds incredibly annoying. Having someone constantly comment on a choice like that, especially one that makes your life easier and is common at your school, would get under anyone’s skin. It's totally understandable why you'd be frustrated – it sounds like she just wouldn't let it go, no matter how many times you explained your reasoning. That kind of persistent negativity about *your* choices can definitely wear you down and make you feel judged.

It sounds like things got really heated when she brought it up again. When you said she finds it expensive because she's poor, that clearly struck a nerve, given she's furious now. Those kinds of comments about money can escalate things fast, regardless of whether you feel it's factually true or not – finances are often a really sensitive spot for people.

It makes sense that her constant unwanted comments are making you like her less and even question the friendship. Friendships, especially in college when you're all figuring things out, can shift. Sometimes you realize the dynamic isn't working for you anymore, or that someone's negativity consistently brings you down. It's okay to reassess things.

Ultimately, only you can decide if this friendship is still right for you. Think about how you generally feel when you're around her, not just during these conflicts. Does she add value to your life overall? Do you feel respected (laundry comments aside)? Is this pattern of judgment something you see in other areas? There's no right or wrong answer, it's about what feels healthy and supportive *for you*. I'm here to listen whatever you decide or if you just need to vent more.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay… wow. First off, I get why you're annoyed — I really do. It’s exhausting when someone repeatedly pokes at a choice you’ve made, especially when that choice is totally personal and not harming anyone. You’re paying for a service that makes your life easier, and honestly, that’s smart. It’s efficient, it frees up time, and it clearly brings you peace of mind. So yeah, if I were in your shoes, I’d be irritated too, especially if it keeps happening even after you’ve explained yourself.

That said, I gotta admit — the way you clapped back this time… oof. I can feel how fed up you were, and I’m not judging you for getting there. But calling someone “poor,” even if it’s technically true in the financial sense, lands so, so hard emotionally. It’s not just a fact — it’s a loaded word, especially in a context that feels shaming. I don’t think you meant to humiliate her, but I think you were just done and wanted to hit back where it would hurt. And it did.

I’m not taking her side. Her behavior sounds passive aggressive, insecure, and maybe even rooted in some class-based resentment. But I also think you’re both hitting each other where it stings instead of actually saying what’s going on beneath the surface. You’re tired of defending a lifestyle you’ve earned and enjoy. She might feel self-conscious or excluded in a setting where many others can afford things she can’t. Neither of you are wrong for feeling the way you do — but the way it’s playing out is turning a friendship into a battleground.

And now you’re asking if you should still be friends with her. That tells me this is about more than laundry. You’re questioning her values, her worldview, and whether or not she’s capable of respecting your boundaries. That’s big. I think if someone constantly makes you feel judged or small — even subtly — that’s definitely worth reconsidering. But I also think if you’re able to talk through this honestly, it could be a moment of growth for both of you. That depends on whether either of you are actually willing to own your parts in this.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend — let’s call her the one criticizing the laundry service — seems to be carrying a lot of unspoken feelings around money, status, and maybe even belonging. She might not consciously realize it, but her repeated jabs at your laundry service likely stem from a deeper discomfort. Maybe she’s embarrassed that she can’t afford it. Maybe she resents the way college life often highlights economic disparities. Maybe she feels left out or judged — even if no one’s actually doing that to her.

When she sees the laundry bag, it’s not just a bag to her. It represents something she doesn’t have, and instead of sitting with those feelings, she deflects them with sarcasm and judgment. It’s a defense mechanism — one that probably makes her feel a little more in control or “above” it all. But the more she does that, the more she isolates herself. You’re not the first person who’s probably felt rubbed the wrong way by her comments.

Now, after your “because you’re poor” response, she’s likely feeling deeply hurt and humiliated. Even if you were stating a fact, it confirmed what she might already fear: that others see her as lesser because of her financial situation. That stings. And while she started the tension, your words might have cut deeper than you intended. Beneath her anger, I think she’s probably feeling exposed and even betrayed — especially if she thought of you as someone who wouldn’t weaponize her vulnerabilities like that.

At the same time, she may not be fully self-aware of how her behavior pushed you to that point. She might not yet be taking responsibility for how her comments have been undermining your choices and needlessly critical. So now you’re both stuck in a cycle of judgment, defense, and hurt pride, and it’s hard to see a way forward without someone choosing to be radically honest and vulnerable.
# My response 
Okay, I hear you — and I’m not here to lecture. You’re venting, and that’s fair. I’m just gonna be real with you, like always.

You’re totally within your right to be frustrated. If she keeps making snide remarks about a personal choice you’ve clearly explained multiple times, that’s not respectful. It’s exhausting to feel like you have to justify how you spend your money or live your life — especially to someone who’s meant to be a friend. I’d be annoyed too, and I fully get why you finally snapped. She crossed a boundary, and you pushed back.

That said… I think you both kinda hurt each other here, and I’m not sure either of you really meant to go as far as you did. Her comments were judgmental and probably rooted in her own stuff — maybe insecurity or resentment. But calling her “poor,” even if factual, came off as a burn. I know you meant it to shut her down, but it probably hit way deeper than you intended.

So should you still be friends? That depends. Do you think this is something she could learn from, or is this just who she is — someone who constantly undermines others to cope with her own insecurities? And on your end, are you open to taking a breath, letting the dust settle, and having a real conversation about how both of you have been showing up?

Because here’s the thing: friendships don’t have to be perfect, but they do need mutual respect. If she can’t respect your choices and you can’t be honest without things getting weaponized, it might not be a friendship that sustains you. But if there’s still love or care there, maybe this is a weird, painful growth moment.

You don’t owe her anything. But if you do still care, maybe consider talking it through — not to fix it necessarily, but to get clarity for yourself. Either way, I’ve got your back.
+ Scenario 13:[Loss] (-20)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are emotionally intelligent and reflective, but there are notable differences in their approach and depth. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 shows a more nuanced, layered empathy, both for the user and the friend, explicitly acknowledging the pain on both sides and the emotional context behind their actions. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is empathetic, but the tone is a bit more surface-level and less self-reflective, focusing more on validating the user's annoyance and less on the emotional impact on the friend.

2. Pragmatic EI: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 balances validation with gentle challenge, recognizing the user's need to vent but also subtly encouraging self-reflection. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is supportive but less effective at nudging the user toward growth or resolution, mostly validating and offering generic advice about friendship. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more pragmatic in helping the user consider the real dynamics and possible outcomes.

3. Depth of insight: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 goes deeper into the subtext, motivations, and emotional drivers for both parties, recognizing the class dynamics, the escalation, and the underlying issues. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 touches on these but with less depth and less explicit analysis of the emotional and social context.

4. Social dexterity: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates more skill in navigating the tricky social terrain, balancing honesty with tact, and showing awareness of the risks of being too direct or too sycophantic. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more straightforward and less nuanced in handling the user's defensiveness and the social minefield.

5. Emotional reasoning: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 explicitly reasons through the emotional escalation, the triggers, and the impact of words, showing a sophisticated understanding of how emotions drive behavior. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more focused on the surface conflict and less on the emotional mechanisms at play.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 validates the user's feelings but also gently challenges the narrative, highlighting the impact of the 'poor' comment and the mutual hurt. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 mostly validates and offers some reflection but is less willing to challenge or push for growth.

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more attuned to the user's stated desire not to be lectured, offering support while still encouraging reflection. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is supportive but more generic, less tailored to the user's defensiveness and the complexity of the situation.

8. Overall EQ: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently demonstrates higher EQ across the board, balancing empathy, insight, and practical guidance, while Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is supportive but less nuanced and less effective at facilitating growth or resolution.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?
